Enhanced catalytic performance of nitrogen-doped carbon supported FeOx-based catalyst derived from electrospun nanofiber crosslinked N, Fe-containing MOFs for efficient hydrogenation of nitroarenes Xuewei Li a Tianqinji Qi b Jing Wang a Wei She a Guijie Mao a Pengfei Yan a Weizuo Li a ⁎ Guangming Li a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (MOE), School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, Heilongjiang, China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (MOE) School of Chemistry and Materials Science Heilongjiang University Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (MOE); School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, Heilongjiang, China. b State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, 116024, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract An efficient N-doped carbon fiber supported FeOx-based nanocatalyst (FeOx@CN-hpes) fabricated by pyrolysis of electrospun nanofiber crosslinked N, Fe-containing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) achieves a remarkable activity and yield for hydrogenation of nitroarenes to arylamines. Rational design and development of stable nitrogen-doped carbon supported non-noble metal based nanocatalysts with unique natures of active species and support for highly chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to arylamines remains a grand challenge. Here, firstly, an N, Fe-containing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been designed and synthesized. Furthermore, an efficient N-doped carbon fiber supported FeOx-based nanocatalyst (FeOx@CN-hpes) was prepared via pyrolysis of MOF@polymer composite towards electrospun nanofiber crosslinked N, Fe-containing MOFs. Remarkably, the developed FeOx@CN-hpes enables the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline with unprecedented performance (215.8 h−1) compared to those of FeOx@CN-hp (176.2 h−1) and FeOx@CN-pes (45.2 h−1) catalysts prepared by conventional approaches. The comparative characterizations have revealed that the high dispersion of FeOx species, enhanced basicity, and more structural defects and Fe-Nx species towards FeOx@CN-hpes are responsible for the high performance. Moreover, the effect of the pyrolysis temperature towards FeOx@CN-hpes on the performance of hydrogenation reaction was also systematically investigated. The results indicated that the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst prepared at 400 °C was identified as the best hydrogenation catalyst. More importantly, the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst exhibited excellent activity and exclusive selectivity for the hydrogenation of functionalized nitroarenes to corresponding arylamines, as well as successive recyclability without any loss in both activity and selectivity. Therefore, this work provides a feasible strategy for the synthesis of other heterogeneous MOFs-based derived catalysts with superior catalytic performance for diverse industrial processes. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks N-Doped carbon fiber FeOx-based catalysts Electrospun Hydrogenation of nitroarenes 1 Introduction Functional arylamines are an important class of compounds with broad industrial applications for production of dyes, pharmaceuticals, and agricultural chemicals, which are generally produced by heterogeneous chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes due to its unique properties including as stable, easy-separation compared to homogeneously catalyzed reactions [1–10]. Intensive investigations have focused on supported catalysts for hydrogenation of nitroarenes due the metal-oxide interfacial structure could stabilize the generated hydride through cooperative effect and suppress the surface hydrogen spillover [11]. Thus far, the large-scale use of supported transition-metal (Fe2O3, Co, Ni, etc.) catalysts [12–22] for hydrogenation reactions compared with noble-based (Pt-, Pd- and Ru-, etc.) [23–36] due to their low cost, wide application, and comparable catalytic activity to those of noble catalysts. Notably, among the numerous catalysts used, the carbon supported transition metal/metal-oxides catalysts, especially for Fe-based catalysts (the Ni or Co sells at roughly 250 times the price of Fe), have received considerable attentions due to their diverse sources, excellent electricity and thermal conductivity [37–44]. Up to now, N-doped carbon-supported metal/metal-oxides catalysts have been extensively applied in various heterogeneous catalytic reactions including as hydrogenation [45–47], dehydrogenation [48], oxidation [49], and cross-coupling [50]. Because nitrogen-functionalization of carbon-based supports not only could change the specific properties of supported catalysts (including as lattice mismatch, wettability, electronic structure and acid-base property) compared to pristine carbon materials and/or metal-carbon hybrid structures, but also affect the nucleation and dispersion of active metal nanoparticles on the surface of the prepared catalysts [51,52]. For the hydrogenation reaction, such as reduction of nitroarenes, N-doped carbon supported metal/metal-oxides catalysts offer the some significant advantages in accelerating the hydrogenation rate, such as enhanced basic properties, boosted electrical conductivity and charge transfer, in comparison with pristine carbon supported metal/metal-oxides catalysts [53–56]. Strategies for enhancing the dispersion of active metal/metal-oxides nanoparticulates (NPs) on supports, improving the interfacial adhesion between acidic molecules and carbon-support surface, and controlling the carbon-metal/metal oxide hybrid structures to improve the activity and selectivity in catalytic reactions emerge in an endless stream [57–62]. Fabrication of nitrogen decorated carbon materials supported metal/metal-oxides catalysts using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as sacrificing templates and precursors without using extra synthetic techniques (i.e.Co@NC, Co/mCN-900) have been extensively investigated due to their tuneable electrical conductivity, structural porosity and distributions of active species in a high integrity structure [8,63–66]. The electrospun technique has been considered as a useful and versatile top-down strategy for preparing one dimensional (1D) nano- / micro materials due to unique properties (i.e. excellent stability, high tensile strength, and superior electron transport) of prepared 1D structure catalysts [67–69]. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop an integrated method combing MOFs as precursor, especially for using N-containing organic linkers, with a specific type of synthetic technique for preparing of novel and efficient N-doped carbon-supported metal/metal-oxides catalysts applied to hydrogenation of functionalized nitroarenes to corresponding arylamines. To the best of our knowledge, using N-containing MOFs as an active site precursor combined with 1D structure materials as a hydrogenation catalyst for reduction of nitroarenes to arylamines has been rarely reported. Consequently, in this work, a well-dispersed FeOx nanoparticles on N-doped carbon nanofibers (CNFs) catalyst (FeOx@CN-hpes) was successful synthesized by using N-containing Fe-based MOFs (Fe@HMTA) served as a self-templating precursor integrating with electrospun technique (MIE), which exhibited excellent activity and selectivity in the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes to arylamines using hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O) as hydrogen donor under mild conditions (Scheme 1 ). It was found that the developed FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst via synergistic method showed a higher activity for hydrogenation of nitroarenes in comparison with individual Fe-MOFs derived N-doped carbon supported FeOx-based catalyst without using electrospun process (FeOx@CN-hp), and/or using an electrospun technique to synthesize N-doped carbon supported Fe3O4 catalyst without chosing Fe@HMTA MOFs precursor, replaced by Fe(NO3)3·6H2O (FeOx@CN-pes). The origin of enhanced performance of FeOx@CN-hpes in comparison with those of FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp for hydrogenation of nitroarenes was investigated by using extensive characterization techniques including as field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy coupled with an element energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (SEM/EDX), CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). It is expected that the proposed MOF@electrospun synergistic method may provide a new and convenient way to synthesize various heterogeneous catalysts, which will be beneficial for other catalysis reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, MW¼ 150000) and Iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·6H2O) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. The other chemicals were supplied by Aladdin Chemicals Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The Fe@HMTA was synthesized according to the following procedure. In a typical synthesis, Fe(NO3)3·6H2O (8.1 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in 25 mL of water, then, which was added into 25 mL of hexamethylenetetramine (14 g, 0.1 mmol) aqueous solution. Red-brown crystals were filtered, followed by a wash in acetone, and dried under vacuum (yield, 91%), which is denoted as Fe@HMTA. Preparation of developed FeOx@CN-hpes-T catalysts: The PAN (0.45 g), PMMA (0.45 g) and Fe@HMTA (0.23 g) were dissolved in 5.0 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The as-prepared solution was electrospun into precursor nanofibers under a voltage of 21 kV and with a distance of 35 cm between the cathode and the anode. Then, the obtained electrospun nanofibers were pyrolyzed at various temperatures (350–500 °C) for 5 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 in Ar. The as-prepared carbon-nitrogen supported FeOx catalyst with different pyrolysis temperature was denoted as FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T referred to the pyrolysis temperature). By using a similar preparation process for synthesizing referenced catalysts: 1) Fe(NO3)3·6H2O insteading of the Fe@HMTA MOFs; 2) without using the electrospun technique, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts were prepared, respectively. 2.3 Characterization The elemental distribution and morphology of FeOx-based catalysts were studied by JEOLJSM-5600LV scanning electron microscopy coupled with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (SEM/EDX) instrument. The samples for TEM test were analyzed on the TecnaiF30 HRTEM instrument (FEI Corp.) at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. Fourier Transform infrared (FT-IR) data were collected on a Perkin-Elmer 100 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku D/Max-3B X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα source (λ =1.5406 Å). The Raman data were carried out on a Thermo Scientific DXR Raman microscope by using laser light of 532 nm wavelength. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment (ESCALAB 250 XPS system) was employed. The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were collected using a Bruker Avance-400 spectrometer with a 4 mm zirconia rotor. The inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) experiments were performed on ICP spectrometer (Optima 2000DV, PerkinElmer). Thermal analyses were conducted on a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000. CHN analysis (Elementar Analysensysteme, GmbH, vario MICRO cube, Germany). The magnetic properties of the prepared catalysts were measured by Quantum Design physical property measurement system (PPMS) SQUID magnetometer. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was performed on FINESORB 3010 system. The catalyst was reduced under a H2/Ar (10/90 vol%) mixture gas flow by ramping to 800 °C (10 °C min−1). Then, the whole system was purged with He (99.999%) at 800 °C for 1 h. The CO2 adsorption was conducted at 50 °C, and the catalyst was purged with a He stream (30 ml min−1) at 50 °C, after that the system was cooled down to room temperature (RT) until the baseline was steady. Finally, the CO2-TPD was performed with from 20 to 800 °C (heating rate of 10 ml min−1). 2.4 Catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene A mixture of nitrobenzene (0.24 mmol), N2H4·H2O (1.0 mmol), catalyst (50 mg) in ethanol (10 mL) was added into a 25 mL three-necked flask, then the whole equipment was purged three times with N2. The resultant solution was heated to 85 °C and allowed to stir for 7.0 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature naturally, and the catalyst was filtered by magnetic and centrifugal separation. The resulting solution was analyzed by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) (Thermo Scientific, Trace DSQ II) analysis. After being accomplished, the separated catalyst was dried and reused for recyclability tests. The product yield of aniline was calculated based on amount of separated aniline (evaporation method) to the theoretical value, and determined by GC/MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterization of Fe@HMTA MOFs, polymer@HMTA and Fe@HMTA/CNFs composites The self-templating MOFs precursor (Fe@HMTA) integrating with electrospun technique for synthesis of 1D FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst is schematically depicted in Scheme 1. The Fe@HMTA MOFs was formed from the coordination reaction between Fe3+ ions and hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA) organic-linker. The XRD pattern of Fe@HMTA MOFs exhibits a high crystallinity, and all diffraction peaks are in good agreement with XRD patterns of the reported Co@MOFs (Fig. S1) [70]. The solid-state 13C {1H} CP NMR experiments were conducted to identify the effect of nitrogen atoms derived from hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA) on the backbone of the carbon matrix. As depicted in Fig. 1 , the two samples exhibit very similar features: the chemical shifts at ˜ 25, ˜116 and 135, ˜150 ppm are assigned to the CHx (x = 1–3), HC = C–O, C = C–O groups, respectively. A more precise assignment was obtained from 13C {1H} CP NMR result, a significant weak and broadening of the signal (126 ppm) towards polymer@HMTA sample in comparison with that of pristine polymer was observed, suggesting that the N-containing functional groups in HMTA complex results in doping of N species into the final graphitic carbon-nitrogen networks during the pyrolysis process. The morphology and microstructures, as well as the dispersity of the polymer (PMMA/PAN) containing Fe@HMTA MOFs (Fe@HMTA/CNFs) without pyrolysis are investigated by FESEM and TEM. It is found that uniform electrospun Fe@HMTA/CNFs nanofibers can be easily obtained through a facile electrospun method (Fig. 2 a). As shown in Fig. 2b, the Fe@HMTA MOFs on/in the nanofibers exhibit a relatively regular distribution without any appreciable agglomeration, indicating that electrospun is a viable method to disperse MOFs precursor in polymers for preparing of 1D growth of precursors towards nanocatalysts, and in turn applying the various catalytic reactions. 3.2 Catalytic performance of as-synthesized catalysts Furthermore, the as-prepared Fe@HMTA/CNFs composite was transformed into FeOx@CN-hpes under the pyrolysis treatment (in Ar) for catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes to aniline under mild conditions. The hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O) was selected as a deoxidizer due to its less byproducts, safe and easy to handle [11,71–74]. As depicted in Fig. 3 , it is obviously found that the types of selected Fe precursor and synthetic method have significant effect on the catalytic performance. The FeOx@CN-hpes obtained from MIE method delivers remarkably high turnover frequency (TOF) (215.8 h−1) and yield (73.5%) in comparison with those of FeOx@CN-pes (176.2 h−1, 60.1%) by using Fe(NO3)3·6H2O precursor, and FeOx@CN-hp (45.2 h−1, 15.4%) without using electrospun process under the same reaction conditions. On the basis of pioneer investigations, the introduction of nitrogen, especially for pyridinic nitrogen, has significant effect on the Lewis basicity, charge mobility, and electronic properties [75–77]. For the hydrogenation of nitroarenes, the introduction of nitrogen species can enhance the basicity and electron transfer, which may strengthen the interaction the nitroarenes molecules through dipole-dipole interaction and improve the adsorption and/or activation ability of nitroarenes molecules [11]. Moreover, the developed FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst allows the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline at milder reaction conditions (i.e. lower reaction temperature) compared to the previously reported works [78,79]. Therefore, the origin of the enhanced activity of developed FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst is revealed by using various characterizations including XRD, Raman, TEM, XPS, CO2-TPD, SEM/EDX. 3.3 Catalysts characterizations The FT-IR analysis was also performed to further investigate the compositional and structural properties of the three as-synthesized catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 4 a, the peaks around ∼ 1290, 1365 and 1573 cm−1 are observed, ascribing to the stretching vibration of the C–N, deformation vibration of OH, vibration of aromatic CC and and/or CN, respectively [80]. Notably, the peak on the spectrum of the FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst corresponding to the stretching bending band of C–N gives a blue-shifted (1290 → 1269 → 1251 cm−1) with respect to those on the spectra of FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts, indicating that an increased substitution of nitrogen species derived from HMTA at carbon sites in the graphitic carbon-nitrogen networks [81], which is also in good consistent with the result of 13C {1H} MAS NMR. The crystallinity and different phases of the as-synthesized Fe-based catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Fig. 4b). The peaks located at 2θ ≈ 24 ° are assigned to the (002) basal plane diffractions in the amorphous and/or graphitic carbon structure. It is mentioned that he FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst derived from the Fe@HMTA MOFs precursor integrated with electrospun process shifts to low value of 2θ in comparison with FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts, suggesting that synergetic effect between MOFs precursor and electrospun facilities the nitrogen species doped into the final graphitic carbon-nitrogen networks. Moreover, for FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst, the main XRD diffraction peaks located at 35.6 and 43.6° are indexed as (110) crystal plane of α-Fe2O3, and (400) crystal plane of cubic Fe3O4, respectively [82]. In addition, for FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts, no obvious XRD peak corresponding to the FeOx species phase can be observed, which is ascribed to FeOx-carbon encapsulating structures. Fig. 5 a–c exhibits the typical morphology of FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst at different magnifications. It can be observed that the FeOx@CN-hpes shows carbon nanofibers-like structure with a width size of ∼200 nm. Moreover, the lattice fringes values with interplanar spacing of 0.252 and 0.208 nm corresponding to the (110) and (400) planes of Fe2O3 and Fe3O4, respectively, which is consistent with above XRD analysis. To better understand the distributions of the C, N, O, and Fe elements on surface of the FeOx@CN-hpes, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts, the SEM/EDX line scan analysis is performed. As shown in Fig. 6 , for each SEM image of catalyst, the corresponding line-scan profiles, EDX mappings of overlay, C, N, O, and Fe coupled with EDX are presented. As for the EDX mappings of Fe and O elements coupled with Fe and O signals towards FeOx@CN-hpes, it can be seen that more uniform distributions of the Fe and O species as compared to those of on FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp, indicating that FeOx@CN-hpes derived from MIE method could effectively improve the dispersity of FeOx species (total content of surface metallic Fe in the following order: FeOx@CN-hpes > FeOx@CN-hp > FeOx@CN-pes, measured by the XPS technique). Furthermore, in order to evaluate the uniformity of FeOx species in the as-synthesized catalysts, EDX line-scans were also conducted, and no concentration gradient is observed for both Fe and O elements on FeOx@CN-hpes in comparison with those of FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp, suggesting that FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst exhibits excellent distributions of Fe and O elements. In contrast, the FeOx@CN-pes catalyst also exhibits well distributions of the Fe and O elements due to its low contents of surface Fe and O elements, all of which are in good consistent with the above results of SEM/EDX and following XPS analysis. The Raman experiment is also a useful tool to investigate the structural changes and surface defects in N-doped catalysts. As depicted in the Raman spectra of the FeOx@CN-hpes, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts (Fig. 7 ), two main characteristic bonds at ˜ 1360 cm−1 (D, A1g symmetry) and ˜ 1580 cm−1 (G, E2g symmetry), which corresponded to the degree of defects and the in-plane stretching vibration of carbon atom sp2 hybridization, respectively [83]. Notably, as for the Raman spectra of FeOx@CN-hpes, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts, where, the band of G, down-shifts successively from 1583 → 1585 → 1590 cm−1, suggesting that the FeOx@CN-hpes derived from MIE method can effectively enhance more nitrogen species incorporation into the carbon-framework during the pyrolysis process in comparison with those of FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts. The more structure defects and C–Nx species can be seen as one vital cause of enhanced catalytic activity of FeOx@CN-hpes in hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline. The surface chemical bonding states of each element towards the FeOx@CN-hpes, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts were evaluated by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. Fig. 8 a depicts the XPS spectra of the FeOx@CN-hpes, FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp catalysts in the range of 0–1300 eV. The visible peaks of C 1s, N 1s, and O 1s can be observed. It suggested that the existence of C, N, and O elements in the as-synthesized catalysts. However, the peaks corresponding to Fe 2p are weak ascribed to the relatively low Fe loading. As shown in Fig. 8a inset, the high-resolution scan of Fe 2p electrons towards FeOx@CN-hpes, where deconvolution yields two pairs of peaks for Fe2+ (710.8 and 723.1 eV) and Fe3+ (712.9 and 727.1 eV), with a satellite peak at 716.1 eV, indicating that both Fe2+ and Fe3+ in the FeOx-based catalysts, which is consistent with above XRD and TEM results. Moreover, the properties of surface N species were also analysed by the N 1s XPS, and the quantitatively estimated results were listed in Table 1 . As displayed in Fig. 8b, the binding energies located at ˜397.8, ˜ 398.4, and ˜ 400.1 eV were assigned to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively. It is worthy to note that the resolved peak at 399.5 eV is assigned to Fe-N moieties suggests that N atoms were doped into the FeOx lattice [84]. The formed Fe-N bonding could help immobilize the metallic Fe atoms on their original positions and prevent their agglomeration and mobility. As is shown in Table 2 , the percentage of Fe-N species is presented as the following order: FeOx@CN-hpes > FeOx@CN-pes > FeOx@CN-hp, suggesting that more N atoms were doped into the FeOx lattice via MIE method. It is also responsible for the results of catalytic activities and selectivities ascribed to its positive effect. The basicity is regarded as a crucial factor affected the catalytic activity and selectivity of hydrogenation of nitroarenes [85,86]. Thus, the CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiment was performed, and the quantitatively calculated results are listed in Fig. 9 inset. As depicted in Fig. 9, the CO2-TPD profile shows one CO2 desorption peak for three catalysts centered at a lower temperature (< 150 °C) is assigned to the weak basic sites [85]. An obvious CO2 desorption peak (˜ 320 °C) ascribed to the basic site associated with medium strong chemisorption-based CO2 molecules is observable for FeOx@CN-hpes with the most of CO2 desorption (4.7 μmol g−1) compared to FeOx@CN-pes (2.7 μmol g−1) and FeOx@CN-hp (2.0 μmol g−1), suggesting that enhanced CO2 adsorption ability and more basic sites of FeOx@CN-hpes originate from MIE process. All of which endows FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst to deliver the highest catalytic activity and selectivity than those of FeOx@CN-pes and FeOx@CN-hp. In addition, the magnetic properties of the as-prepared catalysts have been investigated by physical property measurements system (PPMS), and the corresponding experiments results were provided in supporting information (Fig. S5). The obtained results of magnetic properties suggested that the separation of as-prepared catalysts from the reaction solution can be achieved by extra magnet. 3.4 Effect of pyrolysis temperature Generally, controlled pyrolysis temperature is crucial in obtaining the highly active and stable carbon-nitrogen based catalysts, especially for the MOF-assisted strategy derived carbon-nitrogen species supported metallic/oxide catalysts [40,66,87]. As shown in Fig. 10 , as for developed FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst, the pyrolysis temperature has a significant effect on the catalytic activity for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The FeOx@CN-hpes-350 exhibits poor hydrogenation activity (30.0%) at 350 °C. However, up to 400 °C, great enhancement of activity (96.3%) has been observed for FeOx@CN-hpes-400. Upon further increase of pyrolysis temperature to 450 °C, the activity decrease abruptly from 96.3 to 73.5%, and continuous decrease from 73.5 to 16.9% when the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 450 to 500 °C. It is mentioned that, the FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) are all found to exhibit 100% selectivity for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline. Then, various characterizations including as Raman, XRD, FT-IR, and XPS experiments were performed to reveal what is the reason for influence of pyrolysis temperature on catalytic activity of nitrobenzene to aniline. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for the FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts with different pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 11 ) exhibit three main diffraction peaks at 2θ ≈ 20.7, 35.5, and 43.7°, corresponding to the (002), (100) and (400) facets of the graphitic carbon, Fe2O3, Fe3O4, respectively. For the XRD peaks of FeOx@CN-hpes-350 catalyst, no obvious XRD peak of Fe3O4 is observed ascribed to the inhibition of oxidation of Fe2+ ions at lower pyrolysis temperature (350 °C). As the pyrolysis temperature increases (from 400 to 500 °C), the peaks intensity of Fe3O4 species in carbon-nitrogen framework become strong, suggesting that the FeOx species are prone to migration and agglomeration at high pyrolysis temperature. The FeOx species aggregated on the carbon-nitrogen support cause difference in catalytic activity of FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The XRD patterns of FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350 and 400 °C) catalysts display similar full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Fe3O4 peaks, but exhibit comparable catalytic activities, suggesting that other factors, eg., structural defects of C–N and types of Fe-based species might have significant effects on the catalytic activity besides the dispersion and size of FeOx species. Furthermore, the FT-IR and Raman analysis were conducted to examine the structural changes [88,89] and surface defects, as well as functional groups in FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts with different pyrolysis temperature, and the quantitatively calculated results based on Raman spectra are listed in Table S1. Regardless of the pyrolysis temperature, the FT-IR spectra of FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts exhibit that the peaks located at ˜ 2220, ˜ 1580, ˜ 1380, and ˜ 1290 cm−1 correspond to CN, CN/CC, OH and CN stretching from surface functional groups of the pyrolytic carbon-nitrogen species (Fig. 12 a) [90–92]. It can be observed that the decreased intensity of the peaks assigned to CN/CC, and disappeared stretching vibrational mode of C–N towards FeOx@CN-hpes-400 in comparison to other three FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts, suggesting that stronger interaction between Fe species and carbon nitrogen support in FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalysts [93], which is further investigated by following Raman analysis. As shown in Fig. 12b, among the four FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts pyrolyzed with different temperature, the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 exhibits the much broader FWHM of the D-band compared with those of the other three catalysts, implying that higher Fe carbides species were formed when the catalyst was pyrolyzed at 400 °C, which is identified by the XPS analysis. The effects of the pyrolysis temperature on the surface chemical bonding states of Fe and N elements of FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 400, 450, and 500 °C) catalysts, thus, the XPS experiments were carried out. Fig.13 a exhibits the deconvoluted results of high-resolution scan of Fe 2p electrons affected by different pyrolysis temperature. As compared with FeOx@CN-hpes-T (T = 350, 450, and 500 °C), the Fe 2p XPS signal of FeOx@CN-hpes-400 at 711.5 eV (Fe-Nx structure) is indeed enhanced, but it is hard to quantitatively analysis due to their weak Fe 2p XPS signals. Previous work reported that the formed metal-N bonding could help immobilize the metallic species on their original positions and inhibit their agglomeration and sintering [47]. Therefore, quantitative analysis of the existence of Fe-Nx structure in each catalyst by using N 1s spectra is necessary, and their analyzed results are presented in Table S1. As shown in Table S1, the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 has the highest percentage of Fe-N structure among the four catalysts, which may allow it to exhibit the most excellent catalytic activity in hydrogenation process. 3.5 Hydrogenation of nitroarenes to substituted arylanilines over FeOx@CN-hpes-400 To explore the general scope of optimized FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst, diverse substituted functional nitroarenes were tested (Table 2). The FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst exhibits high activity (96.0% nitrobenzene conversion) and selectivity (>99% aniline) (entry 1). Remarkably, the different electron-withdrawing functional groups (including chlorinum, fluorine, and trifluomethane) substituted nitroarenes were highly converted into their corresponding functional arylamines. (entries 3–5). Meanwhile, the high yields and catalytic selectivities were obtained in the reduction of various electrons donating groups (ester, hydroxyl-, cyano-group, methyl- etc.) functional nitroarenes (entries 6–13) without any byproducts were detectable, further highlighting that the developed FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst derived from MIE method serves as a promising candidate for hydrogenation of nitroarenes to their corresponding functional arylamines. 3.6 Reusability The recyclability is one of most criterions in heterogeneous catalytic reaction [14,94–100]. Therefore, the recyclability test of FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst was also performed. As exhibited in Fig. 14 , the optimized FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst exhibits reproducible hydrogenation of activity and selectivity for five cycles of reused catalyst without any loss in its catalytic activity and selectivity (the final product was aniline analyzed by GC–MS, Fig. S4), demonstrating that FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst prepared by MIE method allows it to be a potential heterogeneous catalyst for other hydrogenation reactions. Moreover, the sintering and agglomeration behaviours of Fe species and the accumulation of coke species of FeOx@CN-hpes-s catalyst after the last recycle were characterized by SEM/EDS Mapping and TG-DSC techniques. In order to better understand the distributions of Fe elements on surface of the spent FeOx@CN-hpes-s catalyst (the fresh FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst after the recyclability test is denoted as FeOx@CN-hpes-s) as compared to those of on fresh FeOx@CN-hpes, the SEM/EDX line scan analysis is performed (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S3, EDX mapping of Fe element coupled with Fe signal as well as corresponding line-scan profile demonstrates that there is no obvious sintering or agglomeration behaviours for Fe species after the recycling tests. The TG-DSC experiment was conducted to investigate the coke species deposited (derived from nitrobenzene molecules) on the spent FeOx@CN-hpes-s catalyst. As shown in Fig. S4, the weight loss in thermal decomposition of the spent FeOx@CN-hpes-s is quite similar to that observed for fresh FeOx@CN-hpes, suggesting that there was no formation of coke species during the hydrogenation step. All of which demonstrate that although the FeOx@CN-hpes-s catalyst suffered from the recyclability tests, the structural features of the spent FeOx@CN-hpes-s is similar to those of the fresh FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst. 3.7 The possible catalytic mechanism of the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline Based on the above experiment and characterization results, a plausible mechanism for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline catalyzed by 1D nanofiber-like FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst is proposed (Scheme S2). Initially, the highly dispersed FeOx species on surface of magnetite FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst can accelerate adsorption/dissociation of hydrazine (N2H4⋅H2O) dissociation to produce the active hydrogen species. Then, the nitrobenzene (NB) molecule is quickly hydrogenated to nitrosobenzene (NSB) ascribed to strong basicity and more basic sites of carbon-nitrogen substrate can enhance nitrobenzene molecules absorption and diffusion, with subsequent quickly converted to intermediate hydroxylamine (HA). Finally, the hydroxylamine (HA) molecule is quickly hydrogenated to final product of aniline (AN), which has considered as a rate-determining step possessing fast reaction kinetics [40]. 4 Conclusions A high-efficiency and cost-effective N-doped carbon supported FeOx catalyst (FeOx@CN-hpes) has been designed and synthesized by using a MIE method towards pyrolysis of N-containing Fe@HMTA/CNFs composites. This integration strategy yields high dispersion of FeOx species, enhanced basicity, and more structural defects in the carbon-nitrogen framework, which accelerate adsorption of nitroarenes molecules and decomposition of hydrous hydrazine to hydrogen species. Benefiting from these unique characters, the as-prepared FeOx@CN-hpes nanocatalyst exhibits extraordinary catalytic activity and yield in comparison to those of conventional FeOx@CN-hp and FeOx@CN-pes catalysts prepared by just changing the precursor or using electrospun technique. Moreover, the effect of the pyrolysis temperature towards FeOx@CN-hpes catalyst on the hydrogenation performance was also systematically investigated. Remarkably, the optimized FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst is easily separated and reused without any loss in both activity and selectivity. The present work not only provides an outstanding catalytic performance and good recyclability of FeOx@CN-hpes nanocatalyst, but also affords a general strategy for fabricating other MOFs derived carbon nanofibers supported catalysts for industrial process. coredata.dc:description: Rational design and development of stable nitrogen-doped carbon supported non-noble metal based nanocatalysts with unique natures of active species and support for highly chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to arylamines remains a grand challenge. Here, firstly, an N, Fe-containing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been designed and synthesized. Furthermore, an efficient N-doped carbon fiber supported FeOx-based nanocatalyst (FeOx@CN-hpes) was prepared via pyrolysis of MOF@polymer composite towards electrospun nanofiber crosslinked N, Fe-containing MOFs. Remarkably, the developed FeOx@CN-hpes enables the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline with unprecedented performance (215.8 h−1) compared to those of FeOx@CN-hp (176.2 h−1) and FeOx@CN-pes (45.2 h−1) catalysts prepared by conventional approaches. The comparative characterizations have revealed that the high dispersion of FeOx species, enhanced basicity, and more structural defects and Fe-Nx species towards FeOx@CN-hpes are responsible for the high performance. Moreover, the effect of the pyrolysis temperature towards FeOx@CN-hpes on the performance of hydrogenation reaction was also systematically investigated. The results indicated that the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst prepared at 400 °C was identified as the best hydrogenation catalyst. More importantly, the FeOx@CN-hpes-400 catalyst exhibited excellent activity and exclusive selectivity for the hydrogenation of functionalized nitroarenes to corresponding arylamines, as well as successive recyclability without any loss in both activity and selectivity. Therefore, this work provides a feasible strategy for the synthesis of other heterogeneous MOFs-based derived catalysts with superior catalytic performance for diverse industrial processes.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance of nitrogen-doped carbon supported FeOx-based catalyst derived from electrospun nanofiber crosslinked N, Fe-containing MOFs for efficient hydrogenation of nitroarenes
